div.head: SCENE, An apartment in Freeman's house.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: (R.) A country boy! ha, ha, ha! How long has this scheme been in your head?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (L.)Some time.— I am now convinced of what you have often been hinting to me, that I am confoundedly cheated by my servants.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh, are you satisfied at last, Mr. Lovel, I always told you, that there is not a worse set of servants in the parish of St. James's than in your kitchen.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: 'Tis with some difficulty I believe it now, Mr. Freeman; though, I must own, my expenses often make me stare.— Philip, I am sure— is an honest fellow; and I will swear for my blacks— If there is a rogue among my folks, it is that surly dog Tom.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You are mistaken in every one. Philip is an hypocritical rascal; Tom has a good deal of surly honesty about him; and for your blacks, they are as bad as your whites.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Pray tell me; is not your Robert acquainted with my people? Perhaps he may give a little light into the thing.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To tell you the truth, Mr. Lovel, your servants are so abandoned, that I have forbid him your house. However, if you have a mind to ask him any question, he shall be forthcoming.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Let us have him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
You shall: But it is an hundred to one if you get any thing out of him; for though he is a very honest fellow,
yet he is so much of a servant, that he'll never tell any thing to the disadvantage of another.—Who waits?— [Enter servant.] (calls off, L.) Send Robert to me.And what was it determined you upon this project at last?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: This letter. It is an anonymous one, and so ought not to be regarded; but it has something honest in it, and put me upon satisfying my curiosity—Read it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I should know something of this hand— (reads) To Peregrine Lovel, Esq— Please your honour,I take the liberty to acquaint your honour, that you are— sadly cheated by your servants—Your honour will find it as I say—I am not willing to be known; whereof, if I am, it may bring one into trouble. So no more from your honour's Servant to command. —Odd and honest! Well—and now what are the steps you intend to take? (returns the letter)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: My plan is this—I gave it out that I was going to my borough house in Devonshire; and yesterday set out with my servant in great form, and lay at Basingstoke—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I ordered the fellow to make the best of his way down into the country, and told him that I would follow him; instead of that. I turned back, and am just come to town.—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How will you get in?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: When I am properly habited, you shall get me introduced to Philip as one of your tenants sons, who wants to be made a good servant of.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: They will certainly discover you.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p:
Never fear; I'll be so countryfied, that you shall not
know me. As they are thoroughly persuaded I am many miles off, they'll be more easily imposed on. Ten to one but they begin to celebrate my departure with a drinking bout, if they are what you describe them-

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Here is Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You ordered me to wait on you, sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I did, Robert.—Robert—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir— (crosses, C.)

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Come here. You know, Robert, I have a good opinion of your integrity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have always endeavoured that your honour should.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Pray, have not you some acquaintance among Mr. Lovel's people?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: A little, please your honour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How do they behave?—We have nobody but friends—you may speak out.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ay, Robert, speak out.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I hope your honours will not insist on my saying any thing in an affair of this kind.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Oh, but we do insist—If you know any thing—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir, I am but a servant myself; and it would not become me to speak ill of a brother-servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Psha! this is false honesty—speak out.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Don't oblige me, good Sir. Consider, Sir, a servant's bread depends upon his carackter.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: But if a servant uses me ill—

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Alas, Sir! what is one man's poison is another man's meat.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You see how they trim for one another.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Service, Sir, is no inheritance.—A servant that is not approved in one place, may give satisfaction in another. Every body must live, your honour.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I like your heartiness as well as your caution; but in my case, it is necessary that I should know the truth.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: The truth, Sir, is not to be spoken at all times: it may bring one into trouble, whereof if—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: "Whereof if" (crosses, L.C.)Pray, Mr. Lovel, let me see that letter again. (Lovel gives the letter)—Aye—It must be so—Robert.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of this letter?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Letter, your honour?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, letter.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I have seen the hand before.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I ask you if you were concerned in writing this letter? You never told me a lie yet, and I expect the truth from you now

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Pray, your honour, don't ask me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Did you write it?—Answer me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I cannot deny it. (bowing)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: What induced you to do it?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I will tell the truth. I have seen such waste and extravagance, and riot and drunkenness, in your kitchen, Sir, that as my master's friend, I could not help discovering it to you.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Go on.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am sorry to say it to your honour, but your honour is not only imposed on, but laughed at by all your servants especially by Philip, who is — a very bad man.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Philip.? An ungrateful dog! — well?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I could not presume to speak to your honour; and therefore I resolved, though but a poor scribe, to write your honour a letter.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Robert, I am greatly indebted to you—Here— (offers money)

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: On any other account than this, I should be proud to receive your honour's bounty; but now I beg to be excused. (refuses the money)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (C.)Thou hast a noble heart, Robert, and I'll not forget you. — Freeman, he must be in the secret.— Wait your master's orders.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I will, your honour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Well sir, are you convinced now?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Convinced? Yes; and I'll be among the scoundrels before night. You or Robert must contrive some way or other to get me introduced to Philip as one of your cottagers boys out of Essex.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: (L.)Ha, ha, ha! You'll make a fine figure.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: They shall make a fine figure.—It must be done this afternoon:—Walk with me across the park, and I'll tell you the whole.—My name shall be Jemmy; and I am come to be a gentleman's servant—and will do my best, and hope to get a good carackter.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But what will you do if you find them rascals?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Discover myself, and blow them all to the devil. Come along.—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
What wretches are ordinary servants, that go hon in the same vulgar track every day! eating, working, and sleeping, —But we, who have the honor to serve the nobility, are of another speeches. We are above the common forms—have servants
to wait upon us, and hare as lazy and luxurious as our masters. Ha! my dear Sir Harry.
How have you done these thousand years?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: My lord duke! your grace's most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well, baronet, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: At Newmarket Doncaster my lord. We have had devilish fine sport.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And a good appearance, I hear. Pox The devil take it, I should have been there; but our hold duchess died, and we were hobliged to keep ouse, for the decency of the thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I picked up fifteen pieces.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Psha! a trifle!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: The viscount's people, have been bloodily demnibly taken in this meeting.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Credit me, baronet, they knew nothing of the turf.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I assure you, my lord, they lost every match; for Crab was beat hollow, Careless threw his rider, and Miss Slammerkin had the distemper.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I'm glad on't. Taste this snuff, sir Harry:

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Rappee?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Right Strasburg I assure you; and of my own importing.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: No! no!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis, I assure you!

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: O No!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.stage: (bowing, and placing his hand on his heart)
sp.p: O, upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The fact is, the city people practice so much adultery that I always import my own snuff—I wish my lord would do the same; but he is so nindolent—When did you see the girls? I saw lady Bab this morning; but, 'fore Gad, whether it be love or reading, she looked as pale as a penitent.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I have just had this card from Lovel's people.— (reads) "Philip and Mrs Kitty present their compliments to Sir Harry, and desire the honour of his company this evening, to be of a small smart party, and eat a bit of supper."

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have the same hinvitation.—Their master it seems is gone to his borough.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: You'll be with us, my lord?—Philip's a blood.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A buck of the first head. I'll tell you a secret,—he's going to be married.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: To Kitty.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: No!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, he is; and I intend to cuckold him. be before him there.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Then we may depend upon your grace for certain ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If our ouse breaks up in a tolderable time, I'll be with you.—Ave you hanything for us?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Yes a little bit of poetry.—I must be at the Cocoa tree club myself till eight.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Heigh-ho! I am quite out of spirits—I had a
demned debauch last night, baronet.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: I adwise your grace to take a wapour bath─ or get shampoodled

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: —Lord Francis, Bob the Bishop, and I, tipt off four bottles of Burgundy a piece.—Ha! there are two fine girls coming!—Faith—Lady Bab—aye, and Lady Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: We'll not join them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
O yes—Bab is a fine wench, notwithstanding her complexion; though I should be glad she would keep her teeth cleaner.—Your English women are demned
negligent about their teeth.—How is your Charlotte in that particular?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: My Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Aye, the world says you are to have her.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I own I did keep her company; but we are off, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Between you and me, she has a plaguy thick pair of legs.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Oh! dem it! that's insufferable.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Besides, she's a fool, and missed her opportunity with the old countess.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I am afraid baronet, you love money. Rot it! I never save a shilling. Indeed I am sure of a place in the excise. Lady Charlotte is to be of the party to night; how do you manage that?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why, we do meet at a third place; are very civil, and look queer, and laugh, and abuse one another, and all that.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A-la-mode, ha! Here they are.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Let us retire.

div.stage: Enter Lady Bab's maid and Lady Charlotte's maid, L.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh fie, lady Charlotte! you are quite indelicate! I am sorry for your taste!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well I say it again, I love Vauxhall Cremorne .

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O my stars! Why there is nobody there but filthy citizens. caniles

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: When did you see the colonel, Lady Bab?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The colonel! I hates the feller. He had the assurance to talk of a creature in Gloucestershire, before my face.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: He is a pretty man for all that. Soldiers, you know, have their mistresses everywhere.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I despise him. How goes on your affair with the baron•t?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The baronet is a stupid wretch, and I shall have nothing to say to him. You are to be at Lovel's to-night Lady Bab?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Unless I alter my mind. I don't admire visiting these commoners, Lady Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh, but Mrs Kitty has taste.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: She infects it.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The duke is fond of her, and he has judgment.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The duke might shew his judgement much better.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: There he is, and the baronet too. Take no notice of them. We'll rally them bye-and-bye.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Dull souls! Let's set up a loud laugh, and leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ay, let us be gone; for the common people do so stare at us;— we shall certainly be mobbed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Duke and Sir Harry come forward.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (L.)They certainly saw us, and are gone off laughing at us; — I must follow. (crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: (L.)No, no.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I must I must have a party of raillery with them, a bong mot, or so. Sir Harry you'll exuese me. Ajew!I'll be with you in the evening, if possible—Though, hark ye; there is a bill depending in our ouse, which the ministry makes a pint of our attending; and so, you know, mum! we must mind the stops of the great fiddle. Ajew!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: What a coxcomb this is! and the fellow can't read. It was but the other day that he was cow boy in the country, then was bound prentice to a periwig maker hair dresser , got into my lord duke's family, and now sets up for a fine gentleman. O tempora! O mores!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Sir Harry, pr'ythee what are we to do at Lovell's when we come there?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: We shall have the fiddles, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: The fiddles! I have done with dancing ever since the last fit of the gout. I'll tell you what, my dear boy, I positively cannot be with them, unless we have a little—
sp.stage: (makes a motion as if with the dice box)

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Fie, my lord duke!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Look you, baronet, I insist on it. Who the devil of any fashion can possibly spend an evening without it? — But I shall lose the girls; — how grave you look! ha, ha, ha, Well let there be fiddles.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: But, my dear lord, I shall be quite miserable without you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Well, I won't be particular; I'll do as the rest do. Tol, lol, lol. O, curse the gout.

div.stage: Exit, R., singing and dancing, R.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: He had the assurance, last winter, to court a tradesman's daughter in the city, with two thousand pounds to her fortune, and got me to write his love letters. He pretended to be an ensign in a marching regiment; so wheedled the old folks into consent, and would have carried the girl off, but was unluckily prevented by the washerwoman — who happened to be his first cousin.
Mr. Philip your servant.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: You are welcome to England, Sir Harry, I hope you received the care, and will do us the honour of your company. My master is gone into Devonshire. We'll have a roaring night

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I'll certainly wait on you.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: The girls will be with us.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Is this a wedding supper, Phillip?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: What do you mean, sir Harry.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: The duke tells me so.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: The duke's a fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Take care what you say; his grace is a bruiser has science .

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I am a pupil of the same academy, and not afraid of him, I assure you. Sir Harry we'll have a noble batch—I have such wine for you!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I am your man, Phil.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p:
Egad the cellar shall bleed: I have some Burgundy that is fit for an emperor—my master would have given his ears for some of it t'other day, to treat my lord what d'ye call him with; but I told him it was all gone! Eh? Charity begins at home eh? Odso, here is Mr. Freeman, my masters intimate friend; he's a
dry one. Don't let us be seen together he'll suspect something.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Remember, Burgundy is the word.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Right—long corks! eh, Phil! (mimicks the drawing of a cork.) Your's.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Now for a cast of my office a starch phiz, a canting phrase, and as many lies as necessary hem!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh, Philip! how do you do, Philip? You have lost your master, I find.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: It is a loss, indeed, sir, so good a gentleman— He must be nearly got into Devonshire by this time. Sir, your servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Why in such a hurry, Philip?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I shall leave the house as little as possible, now his honour is away.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You are in the right, Philip.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Servants at such times are too apt to be negligent and extravagant, sir.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: True; the master's absence is the time to try a good servant in.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: It is so, sir; sir, your servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh, Mr, Philip! pray stay; you must do me a piece of service.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: You command me sir

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I look upon you as one of the best behaved, most sensible, completest— (Philip bows) rascals in the world. (aside)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Your honour is pleased to compliment.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: There is a tenant of mine in Essex, a very honest man—poor fellow! he has a great number of children and they have sent me one of 'em; a tall gawky boy, to make a servant of; but my folks say, they can do nothing with him.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Let me have him, sir,

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: In truth he is an unlicked cub.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p:
I will lick him into something. I warrant you, sir. Now my master is absent, I shall have a good deal
of time upon my hands; and I hate to be idle, sir in two months I'll engage to finish him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I don't doubt it.(aside)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Sir, I have twenty pupils in the parish of St. James's; and for a table or a side-board, or behind a equipage, or in the delivery of a message, or any thing—

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What have you for entrance?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I always leave that to gentlemen's generosity.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Here is a guinea—I beg he may be taken care of.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: That he shall, I promise you (aside) Your honour knows me.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Thoroughly.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: When can I see him, sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Now; directly—call at my my house, and take him in your hand.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Sir, I will be with you in a minute—I will but step into the market to let the next tradesmen know they must not trust any of our servants, now they are at board wages—humph!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: How happy is Mr. Lovel in so excellent a servant!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Ha; ha, ha! This is one of my master's prudent friends, who dines with him three times a week, and thinks he is mighty generous in giving me five guineas at Christmas. - Damn all such sneaking scoundrels, I say. Exit, L.

div.stage: SCENE III.— The Servants Hall in Lovell's House (4th groves) a closet, R.2 E., a table and three chairs.
Kingston, a black footman, L. and Coachman, R., discovered drunk and sleepy.—a knocking at door without, L.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Somebody knocks—Coachy, go—to the door, coachy!

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: I'll not go—do you go—you black dog.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Devil shall fetch me, if I go.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Why then let 'em stay. I'll not go damme. (knocking, L.)Aye, knock the door down, and let yourself in.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ay, ay; knock again— knock again.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Master is gone into Devonshire— He can't be there — so I'll go to sleep—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So will I— I'll go to sleep too.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: You lie, black devil, you shall not go to sleep till I am asleep. I am king of the kitchen.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No, You are not king; but when you are drunk, you are sulky as hell— Here is Cooky coming she is king and queen too.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Somebody has knocked at the door twenty times, and nobody hears—Why, coachman— Kingston—ye drunken bears! why don't one of you go to the door?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: You go, cook, you go—

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Hang me if I go—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Cooky, go; Mollsy, Pollsy, go.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Out, you black toad!— It is none of my business, and go I will not.

div.stage: Sits down, R. C.—loud knocking then a pause and enter Philip with Lovel, disguised, L.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: (C.)I might have stayed at the door all night, as the little man in the play says, if I had not had the key of the door in my pocket. What is come to you all?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: There is John coachman and Kingston as drunk as two bears.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Ah, ha! my lads, what finished already? These are the very best of servants— Poor fellows; I suppose they have been drinking to their master's good journey—ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (L.)No doubt on't.(aside)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Yo ho! get to bed, you dogs, and sleep yourselves sober, that you may be able to get drunk again by-and-by. They are as fast as a church—Jemmy.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Anon?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Do you love drinking?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees I loves ale.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: You dog, you shall swim in Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Burgundy! what be that?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Cook, wake those honest gentlemen, and send them to bed

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: It is impossible to wake them.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I think I could wake 'em sir, if I might, heh?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Do, Jemmy, wake 'em, Jemmy—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Hollo, Mr. Coachman. (gives him a great slap on the face)

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Oh! oh!—what! Zounds! Oh!—damn you.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: What, blackey! blackey! (pulls him by the nose)

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh, oh!—what now?—oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: He, he, he!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—Well done, Jemmy. Cook, see those gentry to bed.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Marry come up, not I indeed.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: She shan't see us to bed—we'll see ourselves to bed.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: We got drunk together, and we'll go to bed together. Exeunt Coachman and Kingston reeling, R.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: You see how we live, boy.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (comes down, L.)Ees, I sees how you live.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: (C)Let the supper be elegant, cook.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Who pays for it?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: My master to be sure; who else? ha, ha, ha, He is rich enough, I hope, ha, ha, ha,

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Humph!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Each of us must take a part, and sink it in our next weekly bills;—that is the way.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Soh!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What boy is this, Philip?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: A boy of Freeman's recommending.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees, I be 'squire Freeman's boy.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.stage: (walking to Lovel, and sticking her arms a-kimbo)
sp.p: Freeman is a stingy hound, and you may tell him I say so—He dines here three times a week, and I never saw the colour of his money yet. (crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! that is good; (aside)Freeman shall have it

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.stage: (goes to R. side and fetches a box)
sp.p: I must step to the tallow-chandler's to dispose of some of my perquisites; and then I'll set about supper.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Well said cook, that is right; the perquisite is the thing, Cook.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Cloe, Cloe! where are you, Cloe?— (calls, R.)

div.stage: Enter Cloe, a black kitchen wench, R.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: I's, misiss.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Take that box, and follow me.

sp.speaker: Cloe.
sp.p: I's, missis— (takes the box) Who is dis? (crosses C., seeing Lovel)Hee, hee, hee!Oh—dis is pretty boy —Hee, hee, hee!—Oh—dis is pretty red hair—Hee, hee, hee! —You shall be in love with me by-and-by — hee, hee, hee!

div.stage: Exit, L., after chucking Lovel under th• chin.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Oh la! what a fine room is this!—Be this the dining room, pray, sir?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: No; our drinking-room.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: La! la! what a fine lady here be —this be madam, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Where have you been Kitty?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I have been disposing of some of master shirts and other linen, which it is a shame his honour should wear any longer. Mrs Barter is above, and waits to know if you have any commands for her.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I shall dispose of my wardrobe to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: A boy of Freeman's; a poor, silly fool.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Thank you

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I intend the entertainment this evening as a compliment to you, Kitty.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I am your humble. Mr. Philip.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: But I beg I may see none of your airs, or hear any of your French gibberish with the duke.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Don't be jealous, Phil.(fawningly)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I intend, before our marriage, to settle something handsome upon you; and with the five hunderd pounds which I have already saved in this extravagant fellow's family—

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: A dog! (aside) Oh! la, la! what, have you got five hundred pounds?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Peace, blockhead.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I'll tell you what you shall do, Phil.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Aye, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: You shall set up a chocolate-house boarding-house , my dear

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Yes, and be cuckolded. for the convenience of your coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: You know my education was a very genteel one.—I was a half-boarder at Chelsea, and I speak French like a native. (awkwardly) Comment vous porter vous Mounsieur?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Psha, psha!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: One is nothing without French—I shall shine in the bar. Do you speak French, boy?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Anan.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Anon O the fool! ha, ha, ha! Come here, do, and let me new-mould you a little. You must be a good boy, and wait upon the gentle folks to-night.

div.stage: (makes him kneel, then ties and powders his hair; Philip fetches the dredging-box from R.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Yes, an't please you, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: His best! O the natural! This is a strange head of hair of thine, boy. It is so coarse, and so carotty.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (rises)All my brothers be red in the pole.

sp.speaker: Philip. and Kitty.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! (loud laugh)

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: (L.)There—now you are somthing like. Come, Philip, give the boy a lesson, and then I'll lecture him out of the Servant's Guide.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: (R.)Come, sir, first, hold up your head:— very well— turn out your toes, sir;—very well—now call coach—

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (C.)What is call coach?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Thus, sir: coach, coach, coach!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Coach, coach, coach! (imitating)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Admirable! the knave has a good ear.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I ha' gotten two ears.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Now, sir tell me a lie.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: O la! I never told a lie in all my life.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Then it is high time you should begin now; what is a servant good for that can't tell a lie?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: And stand in it.—Now I'll lecture him (takes from her pocket a book) This is "The servant's guide to wealth, by Tymothy Shouldernot, formerly servant to several noblemen, and now an officer in the Customs; necessary for all servants."

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Mind, sir, what excellent rules the book contains— and remember them well—come, Kitty, begin—

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Advice to the footman.
sp.l: "Let it for ever be your plan
"To be the master, not the man,
"And do as little as you can.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: He, he, he! Yes, I'll do nothing at all, not I.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.l: To the coachman.
"If your good master on you doats,
"Ne'er leave his house to serve a stranger;
"But pocket hay, and straw, and oats,
"And let the horses eat the manger.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Eat the manger! he, he, he!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I won't give you too much at a time Here, boy, take the book, and read it every night and morning before you say your prayers.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! very good; but I wish we could get that snarling cur, Tom, to make one.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: What is the matter with him?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I don't know he is a queer son of a—

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Oh, I know him; he is one of your sneaking, half bred fellows, that prefers his master's interest to his own.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Here he is.

div.p: —And why won't you make one to-night, Tom? Here's cook and coachman, and all of us—

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I tell you again, I will not make one.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: We shall have something that's good.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: And make your master pay for it.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I warrant, now you think yourself mighty honest. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: A little honester than you. I hope, and not brag neither.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Hark you, Mr. Honesty, don't be saucy.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: This is worth listening to.(aside)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: What, madam, you are afraid are you?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Afraid, sirrah! afraid of what.
sp.stage: (Goes up to Tom, and crosses behind to place again)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Aye, sir, afraid of what?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, afraid of what?
sp.stage: (crossing to him, and back again, to R.)

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I value none of you. I know your tricks.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: What do you know, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Ay, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, what do you know?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I know that you two are in fee with every tradesman belonging to the house. And that you Mr Clodpole, are in a fair way to be hanged.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: What do you strike the boy for?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I'll strike him again. 'Tis such as you that bring a scandal upon as all.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Come, none of your impudence, Tom.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: Egad, madam! The gentry may well complain, when they get such servants as you in their houses. There's your good friend, Mother Barter, the old clothes woman, the greatest thief in town, just now gone out with her apron full of his honour's linen.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and did you never—ha?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: No, never:—I have lived with his honour four years and never took the value of that (snapping his fingers)—His honour is a prince, gives noble wages, and keeps noble company; and yet you two are not contented, but cheat him wherever you can lay your fingers. Shame on you!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: The fellow I thought a rogue, is the only honest servant in my house.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Out, you mealy-mouthed cur.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Well, go tell his honour; do. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I scorn that . Damn I won't be an informer! But yet I hope his honour will find you two out one day or other. That's all.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: (L.)This fellow must be taken care of.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: (C.)I'll do his business for him, when his honour comes to town.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (R. aside)You lie, you scoundrel, you will not. O la! here is a fine gentleman.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ah, ma chere Madamseille! Comment vous portez vous?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: (C.)Fort bien, je vous remercier, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: (R.C.)Now we shall have nonsense by wholesale.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How do you do, Philip?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Your grace's humble servant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But, my dear Kitty (talks apart)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Jemmy—

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Anan ?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Come along with me, and I'll make you free of the cellar.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees, I will; but won't you ask he to drink?(pointing to Duke)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: No, no; he will have his share by-and-by. Come along.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees.

div.stage: Exeunt Philip and Lovel, R. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Indeed I thought your grace an age in coming.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
'Pon honour, hour ouse is but this moment hup. You have a demned vile collection of pictures, I hobserve, above
stairs, Kitty.—Your 'squire as no taste.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: No taste? that's impossible, for he has laid out a vast deal of money.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: There is not a horiginal picture in the whole collection; Where could he pick 'em up?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: He employs three or four men to buy for him, and he always pays for originals.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Donnez moi votre eau de luce—My 'ead aches confoundedly—(She gives a smelling bottle)—Kitty, my dear, I hear you are going to be married.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Pardonnez moi for that.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If you ave a boy, I'll be father, 'faith.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: My lud duke, fie!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: A lapsus lingus—godfather, I mean, 'pon my honor.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I am thinking, my lud, when I had the honour to see you first.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: At the play, Madamseille.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Your grace loves a play?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, it is a dull, hold-fashioned entertainment I ates it; I patronises the Hopera.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Well, give me a good tragedy.(attempting to quote)O, Romo! Romo!—Wherefore art thou Romo? Deny thy father and refuse thy mother, or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love, and I'll no longer be a cabbage-net!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo! bravo! You are devilish handsome, Kate—Kiss me. (offers to kiss her)

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Oh ho! are you thereabouts, my lord duke? That may do very well by-and-by turns Duke over to L. However, you'll never find me behind hand. (offers to kiss her)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Stand off, you are a commoner. Nothing under nobility approaches Kitty.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: You are so devilish proud of your nobility. Now I think, we have more true nobility than you. Let me tell you Sir, a knight of the shire —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: (C.)A knight of the shire! ha, ha, ha! a mighty honour, truly, to represent all the fools in the county.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: (R.)O Lud! This is charming, to see two nobleman quarrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Why, any fool may be born to a title, but only a wise man can make himself honourable.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Well said, Sir Harry, that is good morillity.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I hope you make some difference between hereditary honours and the huzzeys of a mob.(crosses, R.)

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Very smart, my lord.—Now, Sir Harry—

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: If you make use of your hereditary honour to screen you from debt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Zounds, Sir, what do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Hold, hold! I shall have some fine old noble blood spilt here—Have done, Sir Harry—

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Not I; why, he is always valuing himself upon his upper house.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We have dignity.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: What becomes of your dignity, if we refuse the supplies?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Peace, peace! Here's Lady Bab.
Dear Lady Bab!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Mrs Kitty, your servant!How do you do?— My lord duke your servant and Sir Harry too—your's

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Your leddyship's devoted.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I am afraid I have truspassed in point of time (looks at her watch.) But I got into my favourite author.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, I found her leddyship at her studies this morning. Some wicked poem—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O you wretch!—I never read but one book.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: What is your ladyship so fond of?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Shikspur. Did you never read Shikspur?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: I never heard of it.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Shikspur! Shikspur! Who wrote it? No, I never read Shikspur.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then you have an immense pleasure to come.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Shikspur! Who wrote it?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Who wrote it? Why, Ben Jonson.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O, I remember, it was Kolly Kibber!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Well then, I'll read it over one afternoon or other. Here's lady Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Kitty, I thought I never should have reached your house. Such a fit of the cholic seized me. Oh, lady Bab, (crosses to Lady Bab)how long has your ladyship been here? My chairmen were su•h drones coachman was such a drone .—My lord duke! the pink of all good breeding.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Oh, ma'am!—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And Sir Harry! Your servant, Sir Harry.

div.stage: (he bows R.—she turns her back to him, as she curtsies formally, L.—the other characters retire up conversing)

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: (L.)Madam, your servant; I am sorry to hear your ladyship has been ill.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You must give me leave to doubt the sincerity of that sorrow, sir. Remember the park.(fanning herself)

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: (R.)The park! I'll explain that affair, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I want none of your explanifiations, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Dear lady Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Lady C.
sp.p: No, sir; I have observed your coldness of late, and despises you. A trumpery baronet!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: I see how it is; nothing will satisfy you but nobility— That sly dog the Marquis—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: None of your reflections, sir; The Marquis is a person of honour, and above enquiring after a lady's fortune, as you meanly did.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p:
I— I— madam? I scorn such a thing.I only asked what wages you had. I assure you madam—I never—that is to say—egad, I am confounded— My lord
duke, what shall I say to her? Pray help me out.(aside)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Ask her to shew her thick legs ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Enter Philip and Lovel, loaded with bottles, R.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Here, my little peer, here is wine that will ennoble your blood. Both your ladyship's most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Both your ladyships' most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Why, Philip, you have made the boy drunk.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I have made him free of the cellar—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees, I be free, I be very free.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: He has had a smack of every sort of wine, from humble Port to imperial Tokay.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Ees, I have been drinking Kokay.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Go, get you some sleep child, that you may wait on his lordship by-and-by.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Thank you mum—(aside)I will certainly wait on their lordships, and their ladyships too.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Well, ladies, what say you to a dance, and then to supper. Come here—Where are all our people?

div.stage: Enter Coachman, Cook, Kingston, Cloe and Servants, R.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: With submission, the country dances by-and-by.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ay, ay, French dances before supper, and country dances after. I beg the duke and Mrs. Kitty may give us a minuet.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Dear lady Charlotte, consider my poor gout. Sir Harry will oblige us.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Exquese me!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O, a minuet, a minuet!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Play Marshal Thingumbob's minuet.

div.stage: (a minuet by Duke and Kitty, awkward and conceited)

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Mrs. Kitty dances sweetly.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: And my lord duke delightfully.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Well enough for a duke!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Come now to supper—a gentleman and a lady.
sp.stage: (they sit down - the Blacks at a small table, R.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Here is claret, burgundy, and champagne, and a bottle of tokay for the ladies. There are tickets on every bottle. If any gentleman chooses port.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Port!—Tis only fit for a dram.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Lady Bab, what shall I send you? Lady Charlotte, pray be free; the more free, the more welcome, as they say in my country. The gentlemen will be so good as to take care of themselves. (a pause)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Kitty here's a very fine fowl. Shall I send you a walker or a flyer?

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Why, my lord duke, your wit's on the wing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Yes, Sir Harry, and your's seems to have walked off—ha, ha, ha! But come, Lady Charlotte, "Hob or Nob."?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Done—my lord;in Burgundy, if you please.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Here's your sweetheart and mine, and the friends of the company. "you and I and npobody by!"

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Come, ladies and gentlemen, a bumper all round. I have a toast for you— "Here's to the amendment of our masters and mistresses."

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No, no, let us have a song but first—preludo (kisses Kitty) Pray, gentleman put it about

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: See how the black devils kiss.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now, Mrs Kitty, will you honour Sir Arry's muse?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A song a song; ay ay, Sir Harry's song; Sir Harry's song.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: I've left the song in my at in the all; but I'll fetch it if the ladies will exqueeze me.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.p: Oh, certainly, Sir Harry. Exit Sir Harry, L.—a pause.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
My lord—I beg parding, but we is so use the hadress the use of Lords, that I—hem!—Ladies and gentlemen, and (turning to the Blacks) members of
the Ouse of Commons—er—this hopportunity—er—we— er—cannot—er—as I said before—er—allow the hopportunity—er—Sir Arry’s temporious—er—to propoge with unan—er—unannenimous cheers, Sir Arry’s health.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo! (they drink)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Sir Harry, I have the pleasure of informing you, that your absence has given his grace an opportunity of eloquently proposing, and the company the pleasure of drinking your jolly good health.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Mr. Philip, Mrs. Kitty, Lady Bab, Lady Charlotte, and the rest of the nobs and gentry present, I do not possess the noble duke’s horticultural powers of auricular oratory; I have not, like the illustrious duke, | received a classified hedication; but still unable as I is to exasperate my sense of the obligation you have done yourselves—that is, myself—in drinking your health —that is, my health. Unaccustomed as I am to public speaking—as Shakespeare says in his translation of Paradise Lost, “proper queer marrowbones umbie,” which, for the benefit of our fair friends, may be translated, “you can’t make a silk purse out of a sow’s ear. Now them’s my sentiments, and to hact up to them sentiments shall ever be my highest perspiration. Before I sits down on my seat, I begs to propoge a toast and sentimental sentiment: "May the tar wot has lost one leg in the service of his country, never live to see the want of tobacco with the other. (sits)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravo! bravo!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Kitty.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I am really hoarse; but Lady Bab will sing for me. (Sir Harry leads Lady Bab forward)

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Hem; This is a new song, entitled and called, "The Fellow Servant; or, All in a Livery."

sp.l: Come here, Fellow Servant, and listen to me,
I'll show you how those of superior degree
Are only dependants, no better than we.

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Both high and low in this do agree,
'Tis here, Fellow Servant.
And there, Fellow Servant,
And all in a livery.
See yonder fine spark in embroidery drest,
Who bows to the great, and if they smile is blest;
What is he, i'faith, but a servant at best;

sp.speaker: Chorus.
sp.l: Both high and low in this do agree,
'Tis here, Fellow Servant.
And there, Fellow Servant,
And all in a livery.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Now, Mrs. Kitty, will you allow me to recommend a glass of ho-de-wee, just to correct the assiduity of the stomach?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: If your grace pleases. (drinks)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: How do you like the song, my lord duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: It is a demned vile composition.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O very low ! very low indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Can you make a better?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I hope so. I couldn't make a worser.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: That is very conceited.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What is conceited, you scoundrel?

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Scoundrel? You are a rascal.—I'll pull you by the nose.

div.stage: (all rise—Duke and Sir H. come forward)

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Look ye, friend, don't give yourself airs, and make a disturbance among the ladies. If you are a gentleman, behave as sich; name your weapons.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Weapons? What you will— pistols.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Done!—Behind Montague house. Chalk Farm.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Done!— With seconds.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Loaded!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: With powder!

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And ball!

sp.speaker: Sir H.
sp.p: Damme, do you want to murder me?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Oh, for shame, gentlemen! My lord duke—Sir Harry,—the ladies! fie!
sp.stage:
(the
Females rush down screaming—Kitty pretends to faint in a chair. A violent knocking, L.)
sp.p: What the devil can that be, Kitty?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Who can it possibly be?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Kingston, run up stairs and peep. Exit Kingston, L.
It sounds like my master's rap. Pray heaven it is not he! Re-enter Kingston, L. Well, Kingston what it is ?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It is master and Mr. Freeman.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: The devil! What can have brought him back?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: No matter what, away with the things.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Away with the wine, away with the plate. Here, Coachman, Cook. Cloe, Kingston, bear a hand. Out with the candles. Away, away.

sp.speaker: Visitors.
sp.p: What shall we do? What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Run up stairs, ladies.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: No, no, no! He'll see you then.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: What the devil had I to do here!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pox take it, Let's face it out.

sp.speaker: Sir Har.
sp.p: Oh no; these West Indians are very fiery.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I would not have him see any one of you for the world.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Philip! Where's Philip?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Oh the devil! he's certainly coming down stairs. Sir Harry, run down into the cellar. My lord duke, get into the pantry. Away away!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: No, no; do you put their ladyships into the pantry, and I'll take his grace into the coal-hole.

sp.speaker: Visitors.
sp.p: Anywhere, anywhere; up the chimney, if you will.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: There,—in with you.

div.stage: They all go into the pantry, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Philip., Philip!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Coming sir. (aloud) Kitty have you never a good book to be reading of?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Yes here is one.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p:
Egad, this is black Monday with us. Sit down. Seem
to read your book. Here he is as drunk as a piper.

div.stage: Enter Lovel with pistols, affecting to be drunk; Freeman following, L/.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (L.C.)Philip. the son of Alexander the great, where are all my myrmidons? What the devil makes you up so early this morning?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: He is very drunk indeed (aside) Mrs Kitty and I had got into a good book, your honour.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ay, ay, they have been well employed, I dare say ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Come sit down Freeman. Lie you there (Lays his pistols down on table, L.) I come a little unexpectedly; perhaps Philip.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: A good servant is never afraid of being caught sir.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I have some accounts that I must settle—

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Accounts, sir! To night?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Yes to night; I find myself perfectly clear. You shall see I'll settle them in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Your honour will go into the parlour?

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: No, I'll settle 'em all here.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Your honour must not sit here.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: You will certainly take cold, sir; the room has not been washed above an hour.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: What a cursed, lie that is!

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You have just nicked them in the very minute. (aside to Lovel)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I find I have— Mum (aside to Freeman). Get some wine, Philip (Exit Philip, R.U.E.) Though I must eat something before I drink, Kitty, what have you got in the pantry!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: In the pantry? Lard, your honour! we are at board-wages.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I could eat a morsel of cold meat,

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: You shall have it. Here (rises) Open the pantry-door I'll be about your board wages. I have treated you often, now you shall treat your master.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: If I may be believed sir, there is not a scrap of any thing in the world in the pantry.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Well then, we must be contented Freeman. Let us have a crust of bread and a bottle of wine

div.stage: Re-enter Philip, with wine, R. U. E.—a sneeze heard in the pantry, R. door.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: We are undone; undone

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Oh, that is the dukes damned rappee.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Didn't you hear a noise Charles?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Somebody sneezed, I thought.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (rises)There are thieves in the house. I'll be among 'em. (takes a pistol)

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Lack-a-day sir, it was only the cat. They sometimes sneeze for all the world like a Christian. Here, Jack, Jack, He has got a cold sir, puss, puss.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: A cold! then I'll cure him Here, Jack, Jack; puss, puss.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Your honour won't be rash. Pray, your honour don't— (opposing)

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Stand off! Here, Freeman here's a barrel for business with a brace of slugs, and well primed as you see; Freeman I'll hold you five to four, nay, I'll hold you two to one, I hit the cat through the key hole of that pantry door.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Try, try; but I think it impossible.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I am a good marksman—a dead shot. (cocks the pistol,and points it at the pantry door.) Now for it! One, two, three. (a violent shriek,and the door is throw open, all is discovered.) Who the devil are all these? One, two, three, four. Why, Mrs. Kitty, your cat has kittened—two Toms and two Tabbies !

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: They are particular friends of mine Sir; servants to some nobleman in the neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: I told you there were thieves in the house.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I assure your honour they have been entertained at our own expense, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Yes, indeed your honour, if it was the last word I had to speak.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: Take up that bottle. (Philip takes up a bottle with a ticket to it, which has been left at the back, and is going off, R)) Bring it back; do you usually entertain your company with Tokay, Monsieur?

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: I, Sir, treat with wine!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: O yes, "from humble Port to imperial Tokay" too. "Ees, I loves Kokay" (mimicking)

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: How!—Jemmy, my master!

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: Jemmy! The devil!

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: Your honour is at present in liquor; but in the morning, when your honour is recovered, I will set all to rights again.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: (changing his countenance) We'll set all to rights now. There I am sober at your service. What have you to say, Philip? (Philip starts) You may well start. —Go, get out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Sir, I have not the honour to be known to you, but I have the honour to serve His Grace the Duke of—

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: And the impudence familiarly to assume his title. Your grace will give me leave to tell you, that is the door.(Duke crossing, L., bowing)— and if you ever enter there again, I assure you, my lord duke, I will break every bone in your grace's skin.—Begone!—(Exit Duke, L.)I beg their ladyship's pardon; perhaps they cannot go without chairs—Ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: (Sir Harry steals off, across with table cloth hanging out of coat pocket. Lovel puts his foot on the end, which drags it out, several spoons fall with it on the stage).

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Fellers!—Vulgar commoners! Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Downright Hottenpots. Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Philip. and Kitty.
sp.p: I hope your honour will not take away our bread.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: "Five hundred pounds will set you up in a chocolate house— you'll shine in the bar, madam. I have been an eye witness of your roguery, extravagance, and ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Philip and Kitty.
sp.p: Oh, sir— good sir!

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: You madam, may stay here till tomorrow morning — and there madam, is the book you lent me, which I beg you'll read "night and morning before you say your prayers."

sp.speaker: Kitty.
sp.p: I am ruined and undone. Exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: But you Sir, for your villany, and (what I hate worse) your hypocrisy, shall not stay a minute longer in the house; and here comes an honest man to shew you the way out. Your keys, sir.

div.p: Tom, I respect and value you. You are an honest servant and shall never want encouragement. Be so good, Tom as to see that gentleman out of my house (points to Philip.)—and then take charge of the cellar and plate.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I thank your honour; but I would not rise on the ruin of a fellow servant.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: No remonstrance Tom, it shall be as I say.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.p: What a cursed fool have I been.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You have made Tom very happy.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.p: And I intend to make your Robert so, too. Every honest servant should be made happy; and if persons of rank would truly act up to their station it would be impossible that their servants could ape them; — but when they descend to what is ridiculous, it will be in the power of any low creature to follow their example.
